misconceptions.name: Implements an acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The submitted program computes average acceleration from two velocities and a time value, rather than reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that asks for initial velocity, final velocity, and time, then computes and prints the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of those integers are even (using a conditional like n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of only the even integers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t rather than 5 integers.
Program reads three double values instead of five integers.
No loop to handle 5 inputs.
No conditional logic to filter even numbers.
Output message describes average acceleration rather than the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration) instead of the specified task (sum of even numbers), likely due to misreading the assignment or reusing an unrelated template.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the algorithm directly from its requirements: (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop over those 5 values, (3) for each value, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) if it is even, add it to a running sum, and (5) after processing all 5 values, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All identifiers, prompts, and computations in the code are about velocities and acceleration; there is no attempt to read 5 integers, use a loop, or sum even numbers, which strongly indicates the student solved a different problem.

evidence.note: The entire main method is focused on reading v0, v1, and t as doubles and computing average acceleration, rather than reading 5 integers and summing even values.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Task Implemented
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration using three double inputs, completely failing to address the requirements of reading 5 integers, filtering for even numbers, and calculating their sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment, as the provided logic (acceleration calculation) is entirely unrelated to the required task (summing even numbers).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must read exactly five integer inputs, use an iterative structure (loop), apply conditional logic (modulo operation) to filter even numbers, and use an accumulator variable (sum) to calculate their total.
symptoms: Program calculates acceleration instead of sum.
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs.
Missing loops and conditional logic.
Wrong input prompts and output messages.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely submitted the wrong file or fundamentally misinterpreted the assignment instructions, focusing on variables and simple calculations instead of loops and conditionals.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure you are submitting the correct file. The core concepts required are loops, conditional statements using the modulo operator (%), and input reading (Scanner) for integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as the code implements a completely different mathematical function (acceleration) using the wrong number (3 vs 5) and type (double vs int) of inputs.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates acceleration and does not implement any of the required logic for summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Submitted wrong problem entirely
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves an acceleration calculation problem instead of the sum-of-even-numbers problem specified in Q1. This suggests either submission of the wrong file or misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: Not clearly evident, but the submission suggests the student either submitted the wrong code file or is working on a completely different problem
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q1 requires reading 5 integers, filtering for even numbers, and printing their sum. This submission calculates physics acceleration from 3 velocity values and time.
symptoms: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t (physics variables) instead of 5 integers
Only 3 inputs read instead of 5
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
Output is an acceleration value, not a sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission of incorrect assignment code, likely a file management or copy-paste error
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify the correct Q1 code and resubmit. Implement: (1) a loop to read 5 integers, (2) an if-statement checking n%2==0, (3) accumulation of even numbers into a sum variable, (4) print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence that this is the wrong assignment entirely. The code is coherent for a physics problem but has zero overlap with sum-of-evens requirements.

evidence.note: Prompts and reads 3 doubles for physics variables, not 5 integers for sum-of-evens problem

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Calculates and prints physics acceleration formula, not sum of even numbers
Class name and overall structure indicate this is a physics problem, not the integer even-sum problem

misconceptions.name: Incorrect input type and count
misconceptions.description: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers. This demonstrates either misunderstanding of the problem requirements or submission of wrong code.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem requiring 3 floating-point inputs
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q1 requires reading exactly 5 integer values from the user input, not floating-point numbers. Integers are necessary because the even/odd check uses modulo operator behavior on whole numbers.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
Reads only 3 values in a sequence instead of 5
No loop structure to enable reading 5 values
misconceptions.root_cause: Wrong problem submitted; if this were Q1 code, it would indicate misreading or misunderstanding the input specification
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop with nextInt() to read 5 integers: `for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int n = input.nextInt(); ... }`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the code explicitly uses nextDouble() three times and never enters a loop, which is incompatible with reading 5 integers

evidence.note: Uses nextDouble() for 3 variables instead of nextInt() in a loop for 5 integers

misconceptions.name: Solves a different physics problem instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The program is structured to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time instead of summing the even numbers among 5 user-entered integers. There is no accumulator for a sum, no mention of even numbers, and the output message reports "The average acceleration" rather than "Sum of even numbers". This is a conceptual/procedural error about implementing the wrong algorithm for the given specification, not a small typo.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read 5 integers from the user, keep a running total of only the even numbers (those where n % 2 == 0), and then print "Sum of even numbers: X" where X is that total.
symptoms: Prompt asks for "Enter v0, v1, and t:" instead of requesting 5 integers.
Variables are named v0, v1, and t, matching a physics example rather than numbers to sum.
Computation uses the formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of an accumulation of multiple inputs.
Output line prints "The average acceleration is" rather than a sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Very likely the student reused or copied a textbook/example program for average acceleration and did not adapt it to the current problem specification, indicating a misunderstanding of how to translate a new problem statement into an appropriate algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Set aside the acceleration example and restate the required problem in your own words. Then design an algorithm specifically for it: declare an int sum = 0, use a loop to read 5 integers, use an if (n % 2 == 0) check to add even numbers to sum, and finally print "Sum of even numbers: " + sum.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition from English to code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (variable names, prompt, formula, and output text) matches a standard average-acceleration example and has no overlap with the required sum-of-evens behavior.

evidence.note: Entire main method is dedicated to computing and printing average acceleration instead of summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Reads three double values instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads exactly three double values (v0, v1, t) using nextDouble(), whereas the specification requires reading 5 integers. This indicates a mismatch between the required input contract and the implementation.
misconceptions.student_belief: For this task, it is acceptable to read three floating-point values v0, v1, and t using nextDouble().
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read 5 integer values from the user, typically using nextInt() (inside a loop or repeated calls), because the problem states "Enter 5 integers" and uses integer examples.
symptoms: Exactly three calls to input.nextDouble() instead of five reads.
No use of nextInt() at all.
No mechanism to obtain 5 separate numbers from the user.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely followed an existing example that uses three doubles for a physics calculation and did not adjust the type and count of inputs to match the new problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input logic so that you read 5 integers from the user. For example, use a for-loop that runs 5 times and on each iteration call input.nextInt() to get the next integer. Store or process each integer as you read it.
related_concepts: Input contracts (what the program expects from the user)
Using loops to read multiple values
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly uses three nextDouble() calls and never reads integers or five values, directly contradicting the problem statement.

evidence.note: Three nextDouble() calls read v0, v1, and t, instead of reading 5 integers as required.

misconceptions.name: No loop to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to process multiple inputs or apply logic per input value. For the specified problem, a loop (e.g., for or while) is the natural way to handle 5 numbers and apply the even-number test and accumulation repeatedly. The absence of a loop suggests the student has not structured the solution around repeated processing.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to read a small fixed set of values once and perform a single calculation, without designing a looped structure for repeated processing.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle 5 integers and selectively sum the even ones, the code should iterate (e.g., for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)) so that reading, testing (n % 2 == 0), and updating the sum happen repeatedly for each of the 5 inputs.
symptoms: No for, while, or do-while loop anywhere in the program.
Only three read operations followed by a single arithmetic expression.
No repeated structure for processing multiple inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a single-step formula example (average acceleration) that does not require iteration and did not redesign the control flow for a problem involving multiple, similar inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Refactor main so that it uses a loop to handle all 5 numbers. Inside the loop, read one integer, check if it is even, and if so, add it to the running sum. This will align the program structure with the idea of processing a sequence of inputs.
related_concepts: Iterating a fixed number of times
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is clearly no loop in the code while the task naturally lends itself to iteration; however, it is possible (though less likely) that the student knows loops but simply copied a wrong example wholesale.

evidence.note: Entire main method executes linearly with no loop constructs, despite needing to process multiple inputs for the target problem.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never tests whether a value is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0). Instead, it applies a single arithmetic formula (v1 - v0) / t with no branching on input values. For the required problem, a conditional to select only even numbers is central to the logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: For the task as they understood it (computing acceleration), no conditional logic is needed; a direct formula suffices.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only the even numbers among the 5 inputs, the program must use a conditional statement such as if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; } so that odd numbers are skipped and do not affect the total.
symptoms: No if, else if, or switch statements in the code.
No use of the modulus operator (%) to test parity.
All inputs are used in a single arithmetic expression with no filtering.
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the student implemented a different problem that uses a direct arithmetic formula, they did not introduce the required conditional logic to filter inputs based on being even.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each integer, compute n % 2 and use an if-statement to add it to the sum only when the remainder is 0. Practice writing small examples that use if (n % 2 == 0) to reinforce how to filter even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional or parity logic anywhere in the program, which is incompatible with the intended problem. However, this may stem from solving an entirely different task rather than not knowing how conditionals work.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Computation and output involve a direct arithmetic formula with no conditional checks for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Loop Structure
misconceptions.description: Student's code contains no loop structure. The problem requires reading and processing 5 integers sequentially, which necessitates a loop (for or while). The student appears to have solved a single-calculation problem instead.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading multiple input values requires sequential individual read statements without a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When processing multiple values (5 integers), a loop structure (for or while) is the standard and efficient approach. This allows code reuse and scales better. The loop should iterate 5 times, reading one integer per iteration.
symptoms: Code uses only individual variable declarations (v0, v1, t) without iteration structure
No for loop or while loop present in the code
Hard-coded approach that only works for exactly 3 inputs, not 5
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not attempt the correct problem, or is unfamiliar with loop-based input processing patterns.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop that iterates 5 times: `for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)` and read one integer per iteration using `input.nextInt()`. Store each value in an array or process it immediately.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code demonstrably lacks any loop structure. The problem explicitly requires reading 5 values, and the code only reads 3 with sequential statements.

evidence.note: Three hardcoded sequential read statements with no loop structure - scalability problem and incorrect for handling 5 inputs.

misconceptions.name: Missing Even-Number Filtering Logic
misconceptions.description: Student's code contains no conditional logic to check if numbers are even. There is no use of the modulo operator (%) or any if statement to filter for even numbers. Instead, the code performs an unrelated physics calculation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they need to calculate acceleration (a = Δv/Δt) rather than identify and sum even integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The core logic of this problem requires checking each integer to see if it is even using the condition `n % 2 == 0`. Only even numbers should be included in the sum. This is a filtering task, not a physics calculation.
symptoms: Code uses formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of modulo and conditional
No if statement or conditional logic for filtering
No use of the % (modulo) operator for even-number testing
Output is acceleration value, not a sum of filtered numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either did not read the Q1 problem statement, or submitted code from a different (physics/acceleration) assignment. This is not a misconception about how modulo works, but rather solving an entirely different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use the modulo operator: `if (number % 2 == 0)` to test if a number is even. If true, add it to your accumulating sum. Do this inside your loop for each of the 5 integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code demonstrably lacks any modulo operation or conditional logic for testing even numbers. The calculation present (v1 - v0) / t is clearly unrelated to the assignment.

evidence.note: Physics acceleration formula instead of even-number checking logic. No modulo operator or conditional statement present.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Calculation and Output
misconceptions.description: Student's code performs acceleration calculation instead of summing even numbers. The output is a floating-point acceleration value rather than the sum of even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the problem requires calculating and outputting average acceleration from three velocity/time inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires accumulating a running sum of only the even numbers among 5 input integers, then printing that sum. The output format should be: 'Sum of even numbers: [value]'
symptoms: Output prints acceleration instead of sum
No accumulator variable for summing even numbers
Calculation performed is physics-based, not summation-based
Output message is wrong: prints 'The average acceleration is' instead of 'Sum of even numbers:'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student solved an entirely different problem (likely from a physics or kinematics assignment).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Create an integer accumulator variable (e.g., `int sum = 0`). Inside your loop, check if each number is even, and if so, add it to sum: `sum += number`. After the loop, print the result: `System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sum);`
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code outputs acceleration (a physics quantity) rather than a sum. The calculation method is mathematically incompatible with the sum-of-evens task.

evidence.note: Output is acceleration, not sum of even numbers. Incorrect message and wrong calculation entirely.
